trans-unit.source: Radio buttons let users select one option from two or more choices.
trans-unit.target: Radio buttons let users select one option from two or more choices.

trans-unit.source: Guidelines for radio buttons
trans-unit.target: Guidelines for radio buttons

trans-unit.source: Radio buttons
trans-unit.target: Radio buttons

trans-unit.source: Radio buttons let users select one option from two or more choices.
trans-unit.target: Radio buttons let users select one option from two or more choices.

trans-unit.source: Each option is represented by one radio button; a user can select only one radio button in a radio button group.
trans-unit.target: Each option is represented by one radio button; a user can select only one radio button in a radio button group.

trans-unit.source: (If you're curious about the name, radio buttons are named for the channel preset buttons on a radio.)
trans-unit.target: (If you're curious about the name, radio buttons are named for the channel preset buttons on a radio.)

trans-unit.source: Radio buttons
trans-unit.target: Radio buttons

trans-unit.source: Important APIs
trans-unit.target: Important APIs

trans-unit.source: RadioButton class
trans-unit.target: RadioButton class

trans-unit.source: Checked event
trans-unit.target: Checked event

trans-unit.source: IsChecked property
trans-unit.target: IsChecked property

trans-unit.source: Is this the right control?
trans-unit.target: Is this the right control?

trans-unit.source: Use radio buttons to present users with two or more mutually exclusive options, as here.
trans-unit.target: Use radio buttons to present users with two or more mutually exclusive options, as here.

trans-unit.source: A group of radio buttons
trans-unit.target: A group of radio buttons

trans-unit.source: Radio buttons add clarity and weight to very important options in your app.
trans-unit.target: Radio buttons add clarity and weight to very important options in your app.

trans-unit.source: Use radio buttons when the options being presented are important enough to command more screen space and where the clarity of the choice demands very explicit options.
trans-unit.target: Use radio buttons when the options being presented are important enough to command more screen space and where the clarity of the choice demands very explicit options.

trans-unit.source: Radio buttons emphasize all options equally, and that may draw more attention to the options than necessary.
trans-unit.target: Radio buttons emphasize all options equally, and that may draw more attention to the options than necessary.

trans-unit.source: Consider using other controls, unless the options deserve extra attention from the user.
trans-unit.target: Consider using other controls, unless the options deserve extra attention from the user.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the default option is recommended for most users in most situations, use a [drop-down list](lists.md) instead.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the default option is recommended for most users in most situations, use a [drop-down list](lists.md) instead.

trans-unit.source: If there are only two mutually exclusive options, combine them into a single [checkbox](checkbox.md) or [toggle switch](toggles.md).
trans-unit.target: If there are only two mutually exclusive options, combine them into a single [checkbox](checkbox.md) or [toggle switch](toggles.md).

trans-unit.source: For example, use a checkbox for "I agree" instead of two radio buttons for "I agree" and "I don't agree."
trans-unit.target: For example, use a checkbox for "I agree" instead of two radio buttons for "I agree" and "I don't agree."

trans-unit.source: Two ways of presenting a binary choice
trans-unit.target: Two ways of presenting a binary choice

trans-unit.source: When the user can select multiple options, use a [checkbox](checkbox.md) or [list box](lists.md) control instead.
trans-unit.target: When the user can select multiple options, use a [checkbox](checkbox.md) or [list box](lists.md) control instead.

trans-unit.source: Selecting multiple options with check boxes
trans-unit.target: Selecting multiple options with check boxes

trans-unit.source: Don't use radio buttons when the options are numbers that have fixed steps, like 10, 20, 30.
trans-unit.target: Don't use radio buttons when the options are numbers that have fixed steps, like 10, 20, 30.

trans-unit.source: Use a [slider](slider.md) control instead.
trans-unit.target: Use a [slider](slider.md) control instead.

trans-unit.source: If there are more than 8 options, use a [drop-down list](lists.md), a single-select [list box](lists.md), or a [list box](lists.md) instead.
trans-unit.target: If there are more than 8 options, use a [drop-down list](lists.md), a single-select [list box](lists.md), or a [list box](lists.md) instead.

trans-unit.source: If the available options are based on the app’s current context, or can otherwise vary dynamically, use a single-select [list box](lists.md) instead.
trans-unit.target: If the available options are based on the app’s current context, or can otherwise vary dynamically, use a single-select [list box](lists.md) instead.

trans-unit.source: Example
trans-unit.target: Example

trans-unit.source: Radio buttons in the Microsoft Edge browser settings.
trans-unit.target: Radio buttons in the Microsoft Edge browser settings.

trans-unit.source: Radio buttons in the Microsoft Edge browser settings
trans-unit.target: Radio buttons in the Microsoft Edge browser settings

trans-unit.source: Create a radio button
trans-unit.target: Create a radio button

trans-unit.source: Radio buttons work in groups.
trans-unit.target: Radio buttons work in groups.

trans-unit.source: There are 2 ways you can group radio button controls:
trans-unit.target: There are 2 ways you can group radio button controls:

trans-unit.source: Put them inside the same parent container.
trans-unit.target: Put them inside the same parent container.

trans-unit.source: Set the [**GroupName**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.radiobutton.groupname.aspx) property on each radio button to the same value.
trans-unit.target: Set the [**GroupName**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.radiobutton.groupname.aspx) property on each radio button to the same value.

trans-unit.source: **Note**  A group of radio buttons behaves like a single control when accessed via the keyboard.
trans-unit.target: **Note**  A group of radio buttons behaves like a single control when accessed via the keyboard.

trans-unit.source: Only the selected choice is accessible using the Tab key but users can cycle through the group using arrow keys.
trans-unit.target: Only the selected choice is accessible using the Tab key but users can cycle through the group using arrow keys.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the first group of radio buttons is implicitly grouped by being in the same stack panel.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the first group of radio buttons is implicitly grouped by being in the same stack panel.

trans-unit.source: The second group is divided between 2 stack panels, so they're explicitly grouped by GroupName.
trans-unit.target: The second group is divided between 2 stack panels, so they're explicitly grouped by GroupName.

trans-unit.source: The radio button groups look like this.
trans-unit.target: The radio button groups look like this.

trans-unit.source: Radio buttons in two groups
trans-unit.target: Radio buttons in two groups

trans-unit.source: A radio button has two states: *selected* or *cleared*.
trans-unit.target: A radio button has two states: *selected* or *cleared*.

trans-unit.source: When a radio button is selected, its [**IsChecked**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.primitives.togglebutton.ischecked.aspx) property is **true**.
trans-unit.target: When a radio button is selected, its [**IsChecked**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.primitives.togglebutton.ischecked.aspx) property is **true**.

trans-unit.source: When a radio button is cleared, its **IsChecked** property is **false**.
trans-unit.target: When a radio button is cleared, its **IsChecked** property is **false**.

trans-unit.source: A radio button can be cleared by clicking another radio button in the same group, but it cannot be cleared by clicking it again.
trans-unit.target: A radio button can be cleared by clicking another radio button in the same group, but it cannot be cleared by clicking it again.

trans-unit.source: However, you can clear a radio button programmatically by setting its IsChecked property to **false**.
trans-unit.target: However, you can clear a radio button programmatically by setting its IsChecked property to **false**.

trans-unit.source: Recommendations
trans-unit.target: Recommendations

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the purpose and current state of a set of radio buttons is clear.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the purpose and current state of a set of radio buttons is clear.

trans-unit.source: Always give visual feedback when the user taps a radio button.
trans-unit.target: Always give visual feedback when the user taps a radio button.

trans-unit.source: Give visual feedback as the user interacts with radio buttons.
trans-unit.target: Give visual feedback as the user interacts with radio buttons.

trans-unit.source: Normal, pressed, checked, and disabled are examples of radio button states.
trans-unit.target: Normal, pressed, checked, and disabled are examples of radio button states.

trans-unit.source: A user taps a radio button to activate the related option.
trans-unit.target: A user taps a radio button to activate the related option.

trans-unit.source: Tapping an activated option doesn’t deactivate it, but tapping another option transfers activation to that option.
trans-unit.target: Tapping an activated option doesn’t deactivate it, but tapping another option transfers activation to that option.

trans-unit.source: Reserve visual effects and animations for touch feedback, and for the checked state; in the unchecked state, radio button controls should appear unused or inactive (but not disabled).
trans-unit.target: Reserve visual effects and animations for touch feedback, and for the checked state; in the unchecked state, radio button controls should appear unused or inactive (but not disabled).

trans-unit.source: Limit the radio button’s text content to a single line.
trans-unit.target: Limit the radio button’s text content to a single line.

trans-unit.source: You can customize the radio button’s visuals to display a description of the option in smaller font size below the main line of text.
trans-unit.target: You can customize the radio button’s visuals to display a description of the option in smaller font size below the main line of text.

trans-unit.source: If the text content is dynamic, consider how the button will resize and what will happen to visuals around it.
trans-unit.target: If the text content is dynamic, consider how the button will resize and what will happen to visuals around it.

trans-unit.source: Use the default font unless your brand guidelines tell you to use another.
trans-unit.target: Use the default font unless your brand guidelines tell you to use another.

trans-unit.source: Enclose the radio button in a label element so that tapping the label selects the radio button.
trans-unit.target: Enclose the radio button in a label element so that tapping the label selects the radio button.

trans-unit.source: Place the label text after the radio button control, not before or above it.
trans-unit.target: Place the label text after the radio button control, not before or above it.

trans-unit.source: Consider customizing your radio buttons.
trans-unit.target: Consider customizing your radio buttons.

trans-unit.source: By default, a radio button consists of two concentric circles—the inner one filled (and shown when the radio button is checked), the outer one stroked—and some text content.
trans-unit.target: By default, a radio button consists of two concentric circles—the inner one filled (and shown when the radio button is checked), the outer one stroked—and some text content.

trans-unit.source: But we encourage you to be creative.
trans-unit.target: But we encourage you to be creative.

trans-unit.source: Users are comfortable interacting directly with the content of an app.
trans-unit.target: Users are comfortable interacting directly with the content of an app.

trans-unit.source: So you may choose to show the actual content on offer, whether that’s presented with graphics or as subtle textual toggle buttons.
trans-unit.target: So you may choose to show the actual content on offer, whether that’s presented with graphics or as subtle textual toggle buttons.

trans-unit.source: Don't put more than 8 options in a radio button group.
trans-unit.target: Don't put more than 8 options in a radio button group.

trans-unit.source: When you need to present more options, use a [drop-down list](lists.md), [list box](lists.md), or a [list view](lists.md) instead.
trans-unit.target: When you need to present more options, use a [drop-down list](lists.md), [list box](lists.md), or a [list view](lists.md) instead.

trans-unit.source: Don't put two radio button groups next to each other.
trans-unit.target: Don't put two radio button groups next to each other.

trans-unit.source: When two radio button groups are right next to each other, it's difficult to determine which buttons belong to which group.
trans-unit.target: When two radio button groups are right next to each other, it's difficult to determine which buttons belong to which group.

trans-unit.source: Use group labels to separate them.
trans-unit.target: Use group labels to separate them.

trans-unit.target: Additional usage guidance

trans-unit.target: This illustration shows the proper way to position and space radio buttons.
